Posts.Content: I'm sorry to hear this. I used the cold cap and kept my hair - it became thin but it stayed, the cap prolongs your time in the chemo unit as it goes on about an hour before the start of treatment and stays on for about an hour afterwards. I took paracetamol beforehand as I knew it would give me a headache! Your hair needs to be very wet (smothered with conditioner) before it goes on and it needs to be very tight and touch your head all round to be effective. It's horrible but I took mindless candy crush (2 iPads!) to occupy my mind and some music - but the cap makes it hard to have earphones in! It was horrible but it worked really well for me - worth a try if keeping her hair is important to her. Good luck! xA
Posts.Title: Any thoughts on the cap to avoid hair falling out?

Posts.Content: So sorry I'm not nearer up offer help! I didn't have the R creams when I had rads and I was fine. I used a simple body cream and showered before I went. Buit try calling your BCN to see if she can help or call GP on your behalf? Thinking of you xA
Posts.Title: Bloody doctor

Posts.Content: Well done you! amazed that you feel well enough to do more than sleep! X
Posts.Title: had my mastectomy today

Posts.Content: I have dexamethazone, 2 in the morning and 2 at midday for 3 days. Then I have metroclopramide to take as and when I'm nauseous. I just read the leaflets and see that I shouldn't take ibuprofen (which I've been taking for pounding headache!) with dexamethazone.... Oops. Wasn't given choice of meds but may ask for Emend next time. Thanks x
Posts.Title: Headache afterFEC

Posts.Content: I too have had a headache since my first FEC on Thursday, just keep alternating paracetamol & ibuprofen. No temperature. Might be the mix of drugs or the evil cold cap experience. What is emend for?
Posts.Title: Headache afterFEC

Posts.Content: I had my mastectomy on 27 Nov and my first chemo was 15 Jan
Posts.Title: If you had mastectomy followed by chemo...

Posts.Content: I got 2 very reasonably priced from Asda online ( ordered from John Lewis and Amoena also but the Asda ones were good looking, fitted well and were cheapest so others were returned!) I pop a shower scrunchie into the cup pocket - it looks ok and as all the water runs through it, I don’t have a prosthesis to dry. Have a lovely holiday! X
Posts.Title: Post Mastectomy Swimwear

Posts.Content: Sometimes when people ask, I just say "living to fight another day!" But mostly just say "fine" and then sometimes add "as far as I know!" They don't know what else to say... And not do we! Keep smiling - it beats the alternative ! xA
Posts.Title: Why ?

Posts.Content: I had my first chemo last week. The chemo nurse said not to eat a whole list of things .... yogurt?? She also said only to eat peeled fruit & veg - even if fruits are washed, not to eat the skin. Just checking - this is the same one who sent me home with a box of self injections and no practice or demonstration, so I wouldn't be surprised if it's incorrect advice . Anyone else been told this?
Posts.Title: Yogurt

Posts.Content: hello! I used the cold cap and although my hair thinned a bit, I kept it, It's not nice  - freeeeeezing! But it's do able! I had it cut a bit shorter than usual, then before the cap goes on you need to wet your hair and plaster conditioner over it. The cap has to be a really snug fit, touching your head all over. You'll die when you see the machine as it looks like a Victorian medical instrument of torture! It starts about an hour before you have the chemo administered and stays on for about 45 minutes afterwards. Take things to pass the time and take your mind off it. I had 2 iPads to play mindless candy crush (2 so that when I was timed out I could use the other!) some people read but to be honest my head hurt and I couldn't concentrate. But it was worth it. I had the motivation of my daughter's wedding mid chemo - didn't want to wear wig and hat on a warm day if I could avoid it. My hair is thicker than ever and has grown a better colour than I used to dye it! Give it a go - if you don't try it you'll never know. If you can put up with the first half hour, you'll do it - and what's half an hour!? Good luck - let us know how you get on X
Posts.Title: FEC-T and Cold Cap

Posts.Content: Hello Sorry it's so uncomfortable - things will improve.  I didn't have reconstruction, but had good advice after mastectomy - that was to keep gently touching where your breast was - that way your brain gets to know that the breast isn't there anymore. It worked for me. I'm sure you'll get some replies from ladies who have had the same treatment as you - it's the best way to manage this new 'normal' Hope things are better soon x
Posts.Title: Falling to pieces

Posts.Content: Ooh - just had a Muller light yogurt on my cereal - just into week 2. No one showed me the injections, no mention of district nurse. My husband has MS so he injects daily ( different injector..) so he did them for me. I felt a bit resentful and cast adrift that I had so little advice, it made me suspicious of all the advice I had.
Posts.Title: Yogurt

Posts.Content: Thank you Gillie! I've had the op, now chemo & rads to anticipate with trepidation. I haven't stopped drinking, but guess I should start to clear my body in readiness for what lies ahead. Great that you have completed chemo Happy new year! xA
Posts.Title: A 'dry' New Year!

Posts.Content: Just getting my head round all this... Had my mastectomy 27/11, waiting to start chemo. I'm wondering about people's experiences re work - were you able to carry on throughout? Do any work? I'm just not sure how debilitating the chemo is going to be. BCN looks sceptical about return to work, but it's a long time to be off. Are there many good days - good enough to work? I'm a primary school head teacher... 4 months would be a long time to miss from my school! Anyone got experiences / advice / warnings/ handy hints to offer? Thank you xA
Posts.Title: Back to work?

Posts.Content: Thank you for your experiences and advice! Anything you found made the side effects of your chemo more manageable? xA
Posts.Title: Back to work?

Posts.Content: Thank you for such useful responses! I will have 3 FEC and 3Tac. I'm dreading it, actually. I'll see how it goes as far as school is concerned. We may be due an OfSTED inspection in February - stress! I have my daughters wedding on 12 April and need to be on top form by then - and preferably not bald! I suppose there's no good time to discover you have cancer... Thank you to everyone for your kindness and generosity in sharing experiences, xA
Posts.Title: Back to work?

Posts.Content: Hi Peaches It all goes quickly because it's best that way - but also because there are targets to be met, which concentrates the mind! Once everything starts it takes over your life a bit and days become measured by pills potions and appointments - then suddenly you are out the other side, cancer free and a new you. Keep a notebook and jot down any questions you have - take it to every appointment and make notes for future reference! If you don't, you run the risk of going blank, missing your opportunity to ask what you want to ask, and forgetting everything that was said (or mis-remembering!) Good luck for this crazy journey we never expected to take, keep posting, xA
Posts.Title: Results are back

Posts.Content: Be careful, shirleymac! After your radiotherapy ( not to mention surgery and chemo!) you are more tired than you realise. The day after I'd finished everything, I popped into work, keeled over and broke my right arm :(. So now I'm plastered up and unable to drive for a month. Heaps of hassle in so many ways - grrr! So take it easy and don't try to get on with your life as it was BC! Generally, a 6 month check then annual check ups I think once it's over. Good luck for test results and have a great holiday - just don't try to do too much too soon! X
Posts.Title: Treatment finished. Where do I go from here?

Posts.Content: Cathy, if you still have the diet plan I'd be very interested to see it. I'm definitely going o try this! Anne x
Posts.Title: Advice re-fasting for chemotherapy.

Posts.Content: Hello! I had cysts in my left breast 10 and 15 years ago, so when I felt a thickening, not really a lump last year I thought 'Oh blow, another one of them' and thought I'd get referred to have it drained in the summer hols (I'm a teacher). My GP couldnt really feel anything, but referred me to a breast consultant. He had a look and said I'd have mammograms & ultrasound. I look at him and said "you don't think this is a harmless cyst do you?" and he said 'No I,don't". I said "do you think it might be breast cancer?" and he said "I think you might..." These people look at these things all day everyday. He was right - even down to the size of the Tumor you could hardly feel. Had mastectomy, all lymph glands removed and about to start chemotherapy, then radiotherapy & arimadex. Glad I didnt ignore it for any longer....
Posts.Title: Do docs play down cancer until they get biopsy results or can they...

Posts.Content: Hello! I had cysts in my left breast 10 and 15 years ago, so when I felt a thickening, not really a lump last year I thought 'Oh blow, another one of them' and thought I'd get referred to have it drained in the summer hols (I'm a teacher). My GP couldnt really feel anything, but referred me to a breast consultant. He had a look and said I'd have mammograms & ultrasound. I look at him and said "you don't think this is a harmless cyst do you?" and he said 'No I,don't". I said "do you think it might be breast cancer?" and he said "I think you might..." These people look at these things all day everyday. He was right - even down to the size of the Tumor you could hardly feel. Had mastectomy, all lymph glands removed and about to start chemotherapy, then radiotherapy & arimadex. Glad I didnt ignore it for any longer....
Posts.Title: Do docs play down cancer until they get biopsy results or can they...

Posts.Content: I haven't heard of this. I'm mid way through my first FEC and side effects haven't been too bad. Like others I'll do anything to make the treatment more effective. I would probably manage 48 hrs post surgery quite easy to fast on 500 calories because of the nausea. Not sure how easy it would be for the days before. I think I'll give it a go and post about it later!
Posts.Title: Advice re-fasting for chemotherapy.

Posts.Content: Go for it - I echo the above comments. It's not pleasant, so take distractions with you (I played candy crush!). It's just something else to tolerate, but worth a try . My hair thinned but it stayed and after about 6 months was as strong as ever. Good luck!
Posts.Title: fec-t and cold cap

Posts.Content: Hello Sally Lou So sorry you find yourself here. This waiting time is the worst - once you know what you're dealing with and have a treatment plan, time flies by - then suddenly it's over and there's a new you living a different life. I was diagnosed 3 years ago (8cm lobular tumour, 23/32 lymph nodes affected) and this discussion forum was a life line - all those questions you can't voice can be asked here. As George always says, the only silly question is the one you don't ask. So ask away and take strength and support from all the ladies here who have been where you are. Let us know how things go xA
Posts.Title: Diagnosed this week - helpless

Posts.Content: I went for my check with the oncologist who said 'you'll be pleased to hear that I'm discharging you'' after mastectomy for 8cm invasive lobular, 23/32 lymph nodes cancerous - so I'm at increased risk of recurrence - I expressed surprise to be told 'oh, we HARDLY EVER pick anything up at these annual checks. It's ALMOST ALWAYS the ladies that notice something, so by ending annual checks, it frees up lots of appointments for people who need to be seen.' this was Bucks NHS trust - anyone else had this experience? I'll just have to notice something that needs to be checked next year if I want to be seen...
Posts.Title: Annual checks

Posts.Content: Hi Kim I'm a primary school head teacher. I've described the chemotherapy that I'm about to have as my 'keep fit' - they understand that better than a long, scary and complicated word! Hope that helps! Good luck! X
Posts.Title: Feeling bewildered

Posts.Content: It's all doable and there's excellent advice above. I take a bag to chemo with my chemo record book, bottle of water (never needed it - but just in case,,,! I have the cold cap so my sessions are prolonged, but I've kept my hair. I take the iPad and iPad mini to play mindless candycrush (thanks Bongo!) and plenty of music on the iPad. Plenty of tissues ( nose hair gone(so I sniff..) mints, gum, phone, warm gilet or something sleeveless over your top, and someone with you to talk to or just sit there if you can! Good luck - it's not as bad as you expect. X
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy

Posts.Content: Ah that's interesting! Mine wasn't long but was below my ears and I had it cropped and everyone loves it and says it really suits me! It suits ME as I must spend 10-15 minutes blow drying, straightening my hair every morning, and not I just walk out if the shower with a towel round it, take it off, run my fingers through it and I'm done! Love it - what a time save! I look forward to being able to spike it up a bit when this is over. I've been using Simple shampoo as its v gentle (2 for &£4 in Boots just now) good luck and hope it works for you - let us know! ( I lost lots on the pillow in the morning, but it's just thinning- try to alternate the side you sleep on - old habits die hard- it will thin more on the side you sleep on most!) x
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy

Posts.Content: Hello Rhonda Hate that your onc said your prognosis was "poor" Pah! Well here we are doing fine and mostly forgetting that we once had cancer! I'm in S Bucks, mastectomy and chemo at High Wycombe, infection so in Stoke Mandeville overnight, radiotherapy at Mount Vernon! I asked the onc to do the PREDICT tool which compares you with 100 women who had the same type, size, stage, lymph etc. After surgery, chemo, radiotherapy and hormone tablets they can say how many were still alive and kicking 5 years later. Well, I'm 3 years in, you're 4 years in - we're good and going to stay that way! Don't be paranoid - but don't ignore anything.  I fully intend to be around for a very long time - you too?! Don't let worrying about tomorrow stop you enjoying today, xA
Posts.Title: Diagnosed this week - helpless

Posts.Content: Hi Adriana, I had it cut short as I read that it might be mor successful witness weight. Sorry in indecipherable - doing with left hand in dim light of chemo bay! Good luck
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy

Posts.Content: Hello Jo I had mine done at BrowHaus in Covent Garden, after my eyebrows failed to grow back! They've paled rather after 2 years - I'll probably get them re done next year. Love them!  It's s bit uncomfortable but worth it. As I'd had chemo they wanted a note from my oncologist to say she had no objection. Good luck, xA
Posts.Title: Microblading eyebrows

Posts.Content: Hello Dollydaydream! I used to brush my teeth (Using a child's tooth brush and tooth paste) and using mouthwash which I got from the chemo unit, several times a day! Wasn't keen on plain water, but sharper tastes from cordials )lemon or lime) were better. Half a lemon squeezed into hot water sometimes with a little squeeze of honey. Just make yourself drink! Most days I would eat a bag of salt and vinegar crisps - crisps or little salty biscuits seemed to get through the horrid taste. Arrowroot biscuits and ginger nuts were OK to nibble on. Someone recommended making ginger tea - boil sliced root ginger for a couple of minutes, drain and keep to drink when you can. (I found that it gave me indigestion but she swore by it - we're all different and need to try things! I'm 2 years post treatment now (8cm lobular, 23/32 lymph nodes affected) feeling great and loving my new life! You'll get through it and you'll be fine. Keep posting for support and let us know how you get on! Bye for now xA
Posts.Title: Everything tastes so bad!!!!!

Posts.Content: Hello Barbiebee Great advice from Julie - get checked out asap and then start regular gentle stretching exercises, taking paracetamol Or something beforehand if it's too painful. Getting movement back early is a great help in the long run. You do need to persist. I used to just do 2 or 3 stretches in the most peculiar places and sometimes got an odd look - but after what we've been through, should we care? No! You need to get yourself as well as you can for the next stage of your journey and for your future life. Good luck! xA
Posts.Title: Post op arm exercises

Posts.Content: Hello - what a lovely friend! I don't know whether your friend will be having chemo, but if she is you might like to collect her a  few pressies for when she starts. I had a visit from someone I worked with - not even a friend really. She brought mea bag - wouldn't even come in. When I opened it there was: Lip salve Simple shower gel & shampoo Silk pillow case (!) Mints Minty Chewing gum A book Hand cream Black nail varnish Cotton beanie hat A notebook and pen Tic Tacs All sorts of useful lovelies. That became my chemo kit and every time I went and  was a reminder of her amazing kindness. Your post reminded me of her and I thought you might like to do something similar. Other ladies might think if other things you could add - doesn't need to be costly, lots could come from the pound shop - it's just the thought!  I feel quite emotional remembering it 3 years later! Hope all goes well for your friend xA
Posts.Title: Procedure

Posts.Content: Great response Jo - we do see the best ( and worst) at this time! I was able to cross a few off my Christmas card list this year!!! I had a text from a cousin in Liverpool each week when I was having chemo - each ended with YNWA Eventually I googled YNWA - You'll never walk alone!!! So touched! xA
Posts.Title: Procedure

Posts.Content: Hi Tracy You need personal as well as practical support! You need someone to talk everything through with. An appointment with a counsellor would be great - through your GP, or maybe through a cancer centre at the hospital that treated you. They might also have relaxation sessions that would help you manage to sleep. You've had really huge things in your life that you have dealt with in an amazing way. Now it's time to get help to put your thoughts in order . Thinking of you and wishing you all that is good x
Posts.Title: im so tired can someone help me please.

Posts.Content: Hello DebJ, I had the option, but I see oncologist )dr Pwint) at Stoke. I went yo a Look good a Feel Bettter session there, and I find the reception staff at the cancer care unit very friendly and welcoming. I'll go there for the reconstruction when the time comes as that's where the plastic surgeon works from.
Posts.Title: High Wycombe hospital

Posts.Content: After FEC I took mine the following morning and lunchtime - and the next two days. I thought that was what was intended. Two morning and midday. Good luck all I felt was tiredness and mild nausea. All manageable!!!
Posts.Title: Dexamethasone following FEC

Posts.Content: Thank you - I'll try there!
Posts.Title: High Wycombe hospital

Posts.Content: Anyone else going there for their chemo? xA
Posts.Title: High Wycombe hospital

Posts.Content: I finished my treatment (invasive lobular, mastectomy, chemo, rads) just over a year ago and although I rarely contribute now, I read all your posts and continue to be moved and inspired by everyone here.  I saw the oncologist yesterday for my one year check, who told me I was discharged! I asked about annual check ups for 5 years and she told me they are not doing them now. Recurrences of breast cancer are ALMOST ALWAYS picked up by the patient and are HARDLY EVER identified at annual check ups. By ceasing routine annual check ups, this frees up lots of appointments so that they can be very responsive when there is a need. Is this just BUCKINGHAMSHIRE saving money? Has anyone else had the same experience? I'm not confident that I would recognise a recurrence ("Oh, you would!") and am not sure how I feel about this! I thought that with breast cancer, there were national protocols and thought we all got annual checks for five years? Any news or views? xA
Posts.Title: One year check - discharged!

Posts.Content: My cancer was the same as yours. I was told I would have CT scan, bone scan and mammogram. When I asked about MRI the consultant said ts not routinely used at one year check. I was very insistent, saying the cancer had not been picked up previously by mammogram, that I couldn't see how he could be confident that any recurrence would be picked up without MRI. I went on a bit, asking what it would cost for private MRI etc, and eventually  he agreed to request one; I go on Wednesday. Do get back to the consultant about this - its the best chance we have of picking up recurrence of a lobular cancer... good luck! (PS CT & bone scans showed no recurrence, so fingers crossed!)
Posts.Title: follow up for lobular cancer

Posts.Content: Hello Nonnymouse The waiting is the worst bit - but be sure that specialists are looking at your results and planning the best possible treatment and outcomes for you. it really is as personal and individual as that. This is a good place to come for information and support - don't start googling as there is a lot of outdated and inaccurate information floating round! If you do need chemo, you can request the 'cold cap' treatment. I had my daughter's wedding half way through my chemo and didn't want to wear a wig and a hat on a hot day, so was very mitivated to give it a try,  it worked for me. My hair thinned but it stayed and looked OK! Good luck and let us know how you get on! xA
Posts.Title: Question re Breast Cancer chemo?

Posts.Content: Hello Angela I'll be really interested in your responses! I'm 2 years post surgery and was intending DIEP reconstruction but am now getting cold feet. I was big breasted so the other breast will be lifted and reduced at the same time - I'm now chickening out, thinking this is going yo be very major! BUT I would like to be balanced and not with an implant.... I'd like to look normal. I've gained weight which I'd have to lose in order to have the surgery - and the prospect of a big op isn't very motivating! Interested yo hear experiences! Anne
Posts.Title: Delayed reconstruction

Posts.Content: Hello Angela I'll be really interested in your responses! I'm 2 years post surgery and was intending DIEP reconstruction but am now getting cold feet. I was big breasted so the other breast will be lifted and reduced at the same time - I'm now chickening out, thinking this is going yo be very major! BUT I would like to be balanced and not with an implant.... I'd like to look normal. I've gained weight which I'd have to lose in order to have the surgery - and the prospect of a big op isn't very motivating! Interested yo hear experiences! Anne
Posts.Title: Delayed reconstruction

Posts.Content: Hi NonnyMouse I was diagnosed early September 2013 and due for mastectomy mid September. I had a visit to Iraq booked to see my daughter in the October half term, so the surgeon told me to go, see her, enjoy myself and booked my surgery for 3 days after I returned. I was beck at school before Christmas and started chemo on 13th Feb 6 sessions, 3 weekly) then 25 sessions or radiotherapy mon - Fri, Now I'm on anastrozole daily. We're all different and treatments really are tailored to individual needs and circumstances. Once treatment starts its a bit of a runaway train - appointment after appointment, hospital visits, blood tests, recovering... But it's soon over. Keep a notebook and write down any questions you think of and take it with you to each appointment and make sure you ask away! Good luck! xA
Posts.Title: Question re Breast Cancer chemo?

Posts.Content: Hello Linda Yes it's posted - looking forward to hearing from you! X
Posts.Title: Delayed reconstruction

Posts.Content: Can anyone explain what the difference / significance of these figures is? Didnt want to google.. Thanks
Posts.Title: Cancer stage, cancer grade

Posts.Content: Hello Linda Yes it's posted - looking forward to hearing from you! X
Posts.Title: Delayed reconstruction

Posts.Content: Hi Tania! I dont think you'll want a bra for a few days - you'll probable leave hospital with a drain so don't want to fuss with anything unnecessary. I just wore nightie in hospital (only overnight after mx and full lymph gland clearance) I went in an elastic waist skirt, and when I came home, I slipped it on over my nightie, shoes without tights. I only had to go out to the car, my husband just put coat over my shoulders. Hope all goes as well for you as it did for me. Take any painkillers offered (v little pain, bearable). Take snacks in case hospital food is poor - mine was lovely, but it's as well to be prepared! Good luck!
Posts.Title: MX on Friday

Posts.Content: Ah - been out and bought factor 50 moisturiser as my usual (Clinique dramatically different) contains no UV protection. I'll keep out of the sun for the duration, I think! Enough warning stories to make it not worth taking any chances! (cold cap has worked! 3 sessions of FEC with cold cap and have a thinner but full head of hair!) Anyone lost finger / toe nails? I believe black nail varnish helps protect. Good luck you plucky, kind ladies! X
Posts.Title: SUNSHINE!

Posts.Content: Currently undergoing chemo, but love a bit of sunshine, does anyone know if we are allowed to sit out in it? I forgot to ask at the hospital.. Pity to cower indoors in this lovely weather, but if we must.. Thanks! xA
Posts.Title: SUNSHINE!

Posts.Content: Hello! Are you taking anastrozole? Since starting it, I have had wrist pain (and thumbs!) and weakness. I've tried various brands, some worse than others. My once says I'll have to live with it.  Good idea to maybe bring onco appointment forward a bit if you can? xA
Posts.Title: Wrist pain (worried about secondary BC)

Posts.Content: I can't BELIEVE you've been back at work already!!!! You feel like crying under the duvet - do it! I did!(one occasion, I think it was for about 3 days!) You must be kind to yourself and just let yourself recover ready for the next stage of your journey. Your husband sounds a bit like mine - he did come to chemo with me - but then it's all done and dusted and we NEVER talk about it. (Well I do but nearly 3 years down the line, he never mentions it.) Distinct gender difference - women cope with things by talking and men tend to ignore/pretend it's not happening and it will go away (sorry George the exception!) Please take your time - you won't get this chance to fully recover again. I found that once you're back at work everyone assumes you're better and ready to do all that you did before. Well you're not! Take it gently, rest and  - sit in the shade and enjoy the warmth today.  You're going through a lot and you need and deserve to take things v e r y slowly! Take care xA
Posts.Title: Post Surgery Blues

Posts.Content: Hello! I asked for the 'cold cap' and WAs alarmed when I saw it! You have s A really really cold cap like a swimming hat with channels of ice in it, which fits very tightly and has to touch all your scalp and a strap under your chin, then you have it connected to a contraption like an old fashioned hair drier which keeps cold air pumping round. It goes on about 45 mins before chemo starts. And is switched off to 'warm up!' Once chemo ends, but you have to wait a further hour or more before its removed. Before you start, you thoroughly wet your hair and cover it with conditioner. My husband took a pic - it looks like a Victorian instrument of torture. I looked so extremely awful that I deleted the pic! Won't lie, I cried the first time but was determined to persist. I played candy crush mindlessly to take my mind off it. One of the nurses on the chemo ward would look at my sympathetically and say "oh dear - do you want to stop it!" When what I needed was a "You're doing great - stick with it!" My daughter was getting married half way through chemo and I wanted my hair - couldn't bear the thought of wig plus hat on a warm day!! I did keep most of my hair, a very even covering although it thinned.  I'm pleased I did it and photos looked OK! I may have pasted a pic!  If it's important to you, give it a go! xA
Posts.Title: Difference between 'cold cap' and 'scalp-cooling'

Posts.Content: Thank you Dorothee - wine and chocs went down well. The aspirations are generally weekly, but am on antibiotics as I now have an infection and the seroma feels harder and less squishy than it did. If it continues to swell, I'll see the BCN on Friday. I'm trying he deep breathing exercises someone suggested!. Bye for now xA
Posts.Title: Tiresome, depressing seroma

Posts.Content: Thank you Tokes! It's certainly a weird feeling to have fluid sloshing round under your skin. My BCN is reluctant to drain because of the risk of infection but can see that it can't be left. I now have an infection and have antibiotics. I'm waiting for results of CT scan and then a date to start chemo. My daughter gets married on 12 April, so I hope that I'm is reasonable shape for her! I have 4 months of chemo and radiotherapy ahead... I'm a head teacher, so hoping to get back to school for the start of the new term. I'm not sure how much time I'll need to be out if school for this. Do you work? Were you able to continue through treatment? It all seems a bit unreal.. Ah well, new year celebrations ahead! Hope it's a good one for you and thanks for the response, xA
Posts.Title: Tiresome, depressing seroma

Posts.Content: This is my first posting., I had mastectomy and lymph gland clearance on 27 November. Surgery went well, home next day. I'm now waiting or the results of bone, lung, liver scans as there was cancer in 23/32 lymph nodes. The most depressing thing has been a seroma, drained 3 or 4 times (600ml on Friday) and filling and hurting again. Has anyone found a way to reduce the swelling or prevent it filling up agin? Love to hear.. I know more painful experiences lie ahead, but I'd love a quick fix here!! Any advice or experiences gratefully received. Thank you.
Posts.Title: Tiresome, depressing seroma

Posts.Content: Hello! My daughter was getting married half way through my chemotherapy and nothing needed changing! It gave me hope for the future! I was motivated to persist with the cold cap to keep my hair, which worked! I ended up in hospital with an infection the week before, but was out, well and enjoyed the day like no other. It was a really special time for us as a family and I really treasure photos of the 4 of us that day, looking so smart and happy! The icing on the cake came a few weeks later when I learned there was a baby on the way! Change nothing, enjoy everything and make great memories together! X
Posts.Title: Help: Wedding

Posts.Content: Hello! I'm 3 years post-treatment ( kept my hair!) and here are my top tips: Paracetamol! A warm lap quilt that my sister made for me A bag of snacks and tissues 2 iPads to play mindless candy crush! My hospital had a volunteer reflexologist so I booked her for each session if she was available - took my mind off it! I wore bright lippy and sparkly earrings to cheer me up! Good luck! Anne
Posts.Title: New Cold Cap procedure (suggestions to help)

Posts.Content: Hi Andrea andMrs shep, Sorry about your rubbish news - but you can do this. It's all do able. This forum offers practical hints and tips, as well as friendship and moral support. Some people ( George n Jackis, Dorothee and others) are incredibly knowledgeable and generously answer questions and point people in the right direction! Holidays - when I was diagnosed, my mastectomy was put off for a month as I had a trip abroad booked to visit my daughter. My surgeon said a few weeks would make no difference, so to go. So take advice before you cancel! My great news is that all my treatment is over, and it was manageable, with support! Now moving on and you will too. Good luck - just do a day at a time and don't worry about "what next?" just do it! Love x
Posts.Title: New Person!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Andrea andMrs shep, Sorry about your rubbish news - but you can do this. It's all do able. This forum offers practical hints and tips, as well as friendship and moral support. Some people ( George n Jackis, Dorothee and others) are incredibly knowledgeable and generously answer questions and point people in the right direction! Holidays - when I was diagnosed, my mastectomy was put off for a month as I had a trip abroad booked to visit my daughter. My surgeon said a few weeks would make no difference, so to go. So take advice before you cancel! My great news is that all my treatment is over, and it was manageable, with support! Now moving on and you will too. Good luck - just do a day at a time and don't worry about "what next?" just do it! Love x
Posts.Title: New Person!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Ann Had mine done 2 years ago at BrowHaus in Covent Garden ( they have a web site) I loved waking up with eyebrows - they really define your face and frame your eyes. I've just had them re done locally - lots of people do it now, so get recommendations. I love it, it looks very natural and better than the real, rather sparse ones I had before chemo! My eyelashes grew back - they are fine now. I wasn't particularly hairy before, but now I have no hair on arms or legs. Your choice - but I love them! Good luck, whatever you decide to do! xA
Posts.Title: Microblading eyebrows post-chemo?

Posts.Content: Hi ! yes that sounds about right - mine went then - they weren't great to begin with, and never grew back. pubic hair went about the same time, but that reappeared as chemo finished. It wasn't uncomfortable as it grew back.   18 months later,U've just been to Browhaus for semi permanent make up (tiny hairs tattooed) and they look great! hope all goes we'll for you! There's bright light at the end of the tunnel! XA
Posts.Title: Eyebrows

Posts.Content: Thanks Gillie I've never suffered from indigestion so don't know how it feels. It could be that. I'm off to the chemo ward at High Wycombe later to see the wig lady, so will speak to one of the nurses there. I made a ginger drink from a book my daughters bought me (The cancer fighting kitchen) so I might add hot water to it and see if that helps. Thanks for your response!
Posts.Title: Strange sensation

Posts.Content: I went to a Look Good Feel Better session at Mount Vernon hospital. It was most enjoyable and we all enjoyed trying out all the cosmetics in our free goodie bags - all things safe to use and some top makes ( Clinique, Estée Lauder..) it gave everyone a lift. Highly recommended. I wrote to the charity and asked them to pass on all our thanks to the cosmetics companies for their generosity. A great idea! X
Posts.Title: Look Good, Feel Better

Posts.Content: GINGER SYRUP 2 cups water,2 cups sliced unpeeled ginger, 2 tbsp freshly squeezed lemon juice, 2 tbsp honey, (frozen seedless grapes, mint to garnish - both optional. I've used frozen blueberries or nothing!) boil the water & ginger in a saucepan, lower the heat, cover & simmer for 30 mins. Strain & discard the ginger, stir in lemon juice & honey & leave to cool. Add more or less honey or lemon as you see how you like it. I keep it in a jug for a few days, and drink it with fizzy water, or hot or cold still water. Good standby! Enjoy!
Posts.Title: Strange sensation

Posts.Content: From the early hours I've had the sensation of what I can only describe as a 'bubble' in my chest. It doesn't go away with deep breaths and feels a bit scary at times. I'm mid way through my first FEC cycle. My temperature is normal. Anyone else experienced this? Any words of advice? Thanks! x
Posts.Title: Strange sensation

Posts.Content: Bet it's indigestion - thanks Gillie. I knew it was strange but doesn't feel serious. I felt well yesterday, and in the lovely sunshine we had a walk and a stop for cake and hot choc - so enjoying the sense of well being, ate other things later that were not my usual pattern. Serves me right. The Cancer Fighting Kitchen book is by Rebecca Katz, some brilliant ideas but a raft of obscure ingredients. The ginger ale ( you make a cordial) is a good stand by hot or cold with still or fizzy water. Will post recipe if anyone would like it! x
Posts.Title: Strange sensation

Posts.Content: Hello Warrior K i too had all my lymph nodes removed just over a year ago. 23/32 contained cancer cells. It's their job to catch things like that - hopefully, then, they didn't get any further. Into our bodies No evidence of anything at all at my one year checks. i had left mastectomy - no reconstruction, I'll do that next year when I plan to retire. I then had 6 chemo sessions - not nice but yucky side effects don't last llong and it's do able. You'll probably need help with the kids for a few days each cycle. Then I had radiotherapy daily mon - fir for a few weeks. That's ok. dont be too down - it's been caught and removed, anything else just makes things better fir you in the long run. this site is a source of immense support - I don't contribute much now, but I just wanted you to have a resoonse tonight! i'm sure you'll get more messages - try to feel positive that's it's been caught! good night! x
Posts.Title: Removed lump and had axeually clearance on Friday

Posts.Content: Hello! I had 23/32 lymph nodes cancerous - 4 years ago. I have a friend who, 10 years ago, ALL hers contained cancer. Hope they’re just doing a great job for us! X
Posts.Title: Worry over positive lymph nodes

Posts.Content: Hope it's not, but if it is, this site is a great source of advice and support. Fingers crossed for good news x
Posts.Title: breast cancer in men

Posts.Content: Thank you Lizane - wasn't told to bring it out of the fridge to bring up the temp!! Just taken one out and read the instructions - in bold type 'Do not try yo inject yourself unless you have been trained by the doctor or nurse' - had no training, just handed the box in the medi bag you get when you leave. Help! John says he'll do it but am putting it off until it warms up. Glad you told me! Thanks! X
Posts.Title: Self injections for 7 days

Posts.Content: Thanks Russ - I might just ask if I can pop into the surgery each day for the jab! Great idea! X
Posts.Title: Self injections for 7 days

Posts.Content: I don't like to ask for anything, but when friends came on Sunday with a bag of pastries, he cleaned the patio doors inside and out ( just asked me if he could) and they left a container of home made lentil soup for us, I was so delighted that I put pictures on Facebook so other friends might take inspiration! Generally I find the steady tickle of visitors quite wearing and actually wish they would make their own teas and coffees! How ungrateful and mean is that! Let's start by leaving mugs, tea etc by the kettle and when people come, ask them to do it! I'll let you know how it goes! X
Posts.Title: your thoughts please-help should I have to ask or should it be offered...

Posts.Content: I was surprised to be given 7 syringes to self inject immunity boosters after my first FEC that was unexpected. I have to do one this evening and am v apprehensive - any hints and tips? X
Posts.Title: Self injections for 7 days

Posts.Content: No I wasn't given the option of the district nurse ( which I would have gratefully accepted!) my husband self injects as he has MS and has offered to help, but I think I should do it myself. They are fitting in the fridge waiting...!
Posts.Title: Self injections for 7 days

Posts.Content: Hmm ohmyG - these little things that they dont tell you! I took paracetamol & brufen just before the cold cap, then after 4 hours got more paracetamol from the nurse. I took iPad with music to distract me and played candy crush. Take tissues - won't lie, I had a little weep as I was feeling v sorry for myself! Get the first 20 mins over and you can do it. Most people give up and I didn't feel I was encouraged - probably because I'm taking up a place for a long time. It adds about 21/2 hours to your time, but 30-40% keep their hair, so worth a try. I've had a headache most of today, which may or may not be related! Good luck! X
Posts.Title: Self injections for 7 days

Posts.Content: Russ - yes she said to alternate! TimTam, john does his injections at bedtime ( he has MS but has an injector to shoot it in) - that way if you have any side effects, you sleep through them. He just did mine - it was fine.
Posts.Title: Self injections for 7 days

Posts.Content: Done - John just did it for me in my tummy. Luckily he self injects so has plenty of alcohol wipes - there were none in my box!!! Great start. It didn't hurt - he said to take a few deep breaths and relax my shoulders. My hero! X
Posts.Title: Self injections for 7 days

Posts.Content: Hello Cartwheels! I cold capped as I really wanted to try and keep my hair - it was my daughter's wedding half way through chemo and I wanted to look like me in the pics! I hated it - I cried a little bit in the first one, but each one done is an achievement! I had the incredible stroke of luck that a reflexologist was volunteering on the chemo Ward on my mornings, so I had reflexology to take my mind off it. It's hard to be pathetic and cry when someone is massaging your feet!  I took iPad to do mindless candy crush which occupied me and helped the time pass. I also took a lap quilt which kept me warm in the car in the way home. If you have Taxatere next, the cold time is less. You've done the worst part already! I needed a countdown, so before I started I put 6 bottles of champagne on the kitchen window ledge - after each chemo, the first thing I did was take a bottle down and put it in the fridge ready to party when it's all over! The visual reminder that the number kept decreasing was encouraging - treat yourself! I had a wig 'just in case' - but didn't need it and was able to return it brand new to the wig lady - that might be you too! Good luck - don't give up trying if it's important to you, Let us know how it goes! xA
Posts.Title: Cold cap advice please

Posts.Content: Yes - you CAN do it! Go for it - what's to lose? (Apart from a bit of hair!) We'll all be thinking of you and sending warm vibes! xA
Posts.Title: Cold cap advice please

Posts.Content: That's great news that your lymph nodes were clear (mine weren't :(. ) the oncologist described the chemo / radiotherapy as a 'mop up' operation, a sort of insurance policy in case ant rogue cells are remaining. It then makes a recurrence less likely. I too had huge problems with fluid - at one stage 600ml a week being drained! This week it was only 60ml so it's definitely calming down and dissipating. I read that deep breathing exercises helps. I did them and perhaps it helped - who knows! They haloed me fall asleep anyway! Very pleased your husbands cancer is gone. Good luck x
Posts.Title: Phew.

Posts.Content: Hi Kat87, it's a horrible time. Why not phone the breast clinic at the hospital you will be attending and speak to one of the breast care nurses - she may be able to answer your question. They always tell you what they can, as soon as they can. Good luck! xA
Posts.Title: will they be able to tell me something on the day of my tests?

Posts.Content: Google mastectomy cushions - one of my work friends found a pattern on the Internet (a sort of heart shape) and made me one and it was under my arm sight and day for about a month. See if someone can make you one - until then, improvise with a small soft cushio. It does get better, a bit better each day - promise! x
Posts.Title: Feeling rough at minute

Posts.Content: Hello! I also had L side mastectomy. I was amazed at how quickly and easily it healed (I too have large boobs) and v little pain - just patacetamol or ibruprofen. I had the op in the afternoon and came home the next lunchtime - but wasn't chased out! I also had lymph node clearance, so I had a drain, but that wasn't a problem. I wobbled round without a bra for the first week or so, then my daughter bought me a couple of M&S mastectomy bras, which I used with a softie that I was given at the hospital to pad the empty cup. Lots of people praise tha Asda comfort bras. Don't buy stuff yet - use your old T shirt to sleep in, and it might not gape as much as you think! Someone I work with gave me a little heart shaped cushion that I could tuck under my arm to sleep - you can find them on the internet. It just helped and protected the scar. I was advised not to put anything on the scar for a while. Take advice - I used bio oil (or superdrug equivalent) once it was completely healed. Good luck - you will be FINE! Keep logging on here for support, information and encouragement, Bye for now xA
Posts.Title: Having left sided masectomy without reconstruction in 2 weeks, please...

Posts.Content: Hi Sarah Sorry you find yourself here but it will be over in no time. I'm 3 years post diagnosis now. I still look in. I used to be on this site half the night when I couldn't sleep and found it to be a source of great encouragement, information and reassurance! You Han ask anything and one of the ladies ( or George!) will always help you. That's why you're here! You need to be fully informed with as much ammunition in your armoury as possible  Good luck xA
Posts.Title: Stage 3 breast cancer help & how to tell my children

Posts.Content: Yes - make sure the children's headteacher and teachers are aware and they will keep a special eye on them.  They will be going to new teachers next week who may not know them very well, but if you alert them they will speak with last years teachers and be alert to any behaviour changes. Maybe make sure they have your email address to keep in touch and you can email them if you can't get in to see them. xA
Posts.Title: Stage 3 breast cancer help & how to tell my children

Posts.Content: Hello My hysteroscopy is on Monday! I've elected to have it under general anaesthetic as it sounds potentially uncomfortable.my brother is an anaesthetist and said it's a procedure I might not want to be awake for! I'm well post menopause and 3 years post mastectomy, chemo & radiotherapy. I take anastrozole - could be a side effect. It was only a little spotting about a month ago and nothing since. I've had jelly on the belly scan and internal scan which shows thickening more than usual and what looks to be a fibroid. SO on Monday it's the hysteroscopy and biopsy of the fibroid.  I'll let you know how it goes! xA
Posts.Title: hysteroscopy
